Velukh's World of Warcraft Blog

Why Battle for Azeroth Failed

Let me start by saying that I have loved playing WoW for a really long time. I have played the game in a lot of ways and some of the best gaming memories of my life are in this game. I've met a lot of cool people through WoW and started off the beginning of BFA full of optimism and excitement about what the future held after the grand-slam that I viewed Legion as. Unfortunately, much like WoW's apparent subscriber numbers, my optimism and excitement has waned considerably since then.

Many members of the WoW community have voiced their ultimate displeasure about one of BFA's most visible and damning aspect, Azerite Armor. While the problems with Azerite Armor are real I contend that the more serious problems with BFA go deeper than that and are ultimately the result of intentional decisions made by Blizzard developers.

What Blizzard took away

Ultimately Blizzard took away a lot from their player base in the transition from Legion to Battle for Azeroth. Although they attempted to replace some of the pieces in BFA their implementation fell well short of giving us back something commensurate to what was taken away.

  • Artifact Traits and Abilities
  • Legendaries
  • Class Sets
  • Added many spells and abilities onto the global cooldown

While some of the Artifact traits and legendary effects were baked into existing spells or abilities or turned into talents they were weakened. Or in the case of talents we went from having both the legendary effect AND the talent for that tier to having to choose a neutered legendary effect OR the talent for that tier. Either way you slice it taking away all of these things at the same time resulted in a perceived loss of character power.

What they gave us in return

What we received in return was... Azerite armor. That's it. The sole thing responsible for replacing the extreme amount of power taken away from us was the one piece of the system that's despised by the community.

No new talents. No new spells or abilities. Just... Azerite armor.

This ultimately led to the feeling that at best your character is stagnate from 110 to 120 and at worst your character actually feels like it regressed. And if there's one rule about RPGS it is that higher level characters should feel significantly higher powered than lower level characters. Beyond the sheer fact of equipping higher item level armor there is no significant difference between a 110 character and a 120 character. In a game like WoW, that's a big problem.

Pray deliver me from RNGesus

WoW, at least recently, has had a tremendous reliance on RNG. Since the only way to make your 120 character feel more powerful than they were at 110 is through equipping high level armor how you acquire that armor becomes more important. Up until very recently the only way to acquire any item is through the luck of the dice roll. They also simultaneously take away 1 of our bonus rolls; knowing that we need multiple pieces of Azerite armor and knowing that we also have to acquire weapons on a regular basis they take away 1 of the best means, through bad luck protection, at actually getting the item that you want. It is incredibly unsatisfying to have an entire week's worth of endgame content result in no items and your 2 bonus rolls result in meaningless artifact power.

While the dev team recognizes this problem in one regard, they recently allow for the purchase of Azerite armor through a special in-game currency, they don't seem able to fully commit to the idea of a currency based loot system; all the other pieces you need still rely on the same RNG system. If items for all slots were able to be purchsed at the very least there is discernible progress made every week toward my character getting better. As it stands right now it is a flip of the coin every week whether or not your character will have any progress made on it. If you get unlucky with the dice rolls and those weeks start numbering 3-4 it leaves you feel immensely unsatisfied.

There's still hope...

For the next expansion anyway. The dev team also seems to make decisions with the sole intent of making the game less fun; adding affixes to all M+ keys and destroying the low level key ecosystem, not having paragon reputation from the beginning, time-gating allied races while simultaneously marketing them as a key feature of the expansion, not allowing reputation tokens to be shared across alts, and simply neutering the items in world treasure chests were all conscious decisions whose seemingly only impact is to make the game less enjoyable and to take away from the player base. It will take time to reverse course, if the dev team ever decides to, and given the current state of Blizzard it does not seem as if that faith is well placed.
